Question_1.Context: The study aimed to develop a methodology for thermoelastic analysis using experimental temperature data and numerical displacement evaluation.
Question_1.Question: What was the purpose of using thermal imaging in the experimental setup?
Question_1.Source: The experimental procedure relied on the simultaneous acquisition of the temperature and displacement fields acting on a surface using two optical measurement methods, thermal imaging and DIC analysis.

Question_2.Context: The study utilized a CNC marker device for marking speckle patterns on the surface.
Question_2.Question: What was the advantage of using the CNC marker device for speckle pattern generation?
Question_2.A: Consistent reproduction of speckle size and distribution
Question_2.B: Lower cost compared to other methods
Question_2.Source: The developed surface marking procedure can be adapted for any other device, like 3d printers, to mark the speckle patterns independent of the surface complexity.

Question_3.Context: The study compared different polynomial functions for approximating the temperature field.
Question_3.Question: What was the purpose of approximating the temperature field with polynomial functions?
Question_3.C: To convert domain integrals into boundary equivalents
Question_3.Source: The BEM formulation used in this procedure, obtained from an RIM application, required the temperature field to be input as a function, introducing a possible error source to the analysis.

Question_4.Context: The study involved the comparison of numerical and experimental displacement fields.
Question_4.Question: What was the main purpose of comparing the numerical and experimental displacement fields?
Question_4.A: To determine the accuracy of the experimental setup
Question_4.Source: The observed good agreement between the numerical and experimental results points toward the viability and good accuracy of the proposed methodology.

Question_5.Context: The study discussed the importance of the speckle pattern in DIC analysis.
Question_5.Question: Why is the quality of the speckle pattern crucial in DIC analysis?
Question_5.Source: The good quality of the speckle pattern used in the DIC analyses was assured by using a CNC marker device specially developed for this work.

Question_6.Context: The study utilized thermal imaging for acquiring temperature data.
Question_6.Question: What was the purpose of acquiring the temperature data using thermal imaging?
Question_6.Source: The experimentally acquired temperature fields were used as inputs for a numerical BEM routine that calculates the consequent displacement fields.

Question_7.Context: The study employed a DIC system for displacement analysis.
Question_7.Question: What was the role of the DIC system in the experimental setup?
Question_7.Source: The good quality of the speckle pattern used in the DIC analyses was assured by using a CNC marker device specially developed for this work.

Question_8.Context: The study discussed the use of polynomial functions for approximating temperature data.
Question_8.Question: Why was it necessary to approximate the temperature data with polynomial functions?
Question_8.C: To convert domain integrals into boundary equivalents
Question_8.Source: The BEM formulation used in this procedure, obtained from an RIM application, required the temperature field to be input as a function, introducing a possible error source to the analysis.

Question_9.Context: The study compared different polynomial functions for approximating the temperature field.
Question_9.Question: What was the outcome of comparing the different polynomial functions for approximating the temperature field?
Question_9.A: Biquadratic function showed the highest accuracy
Question_9.B: Biquartic function had the lowest error
Question_9.C: All polynomial functions showed similar accuracy
Question_9.D: Bicubic function was the most accurate
Question_9.Source: The proximity of the resultant values provided by each polynomial function is once again evinced by the error data.

Question_10.Context: The study discussed the experimental setup for acquiring temperature and displacement data.
Question_10.Question: Why was it important to have a controlled environment during the experimental setup?
Question_10.Source: The experimental procedure relied on the simultaneous acquisition of the temperature and displacement fields acting on a surface using two optical measurement methods, thermal imaging and DIC analysis.
